questions.question: What is the primary purpose of vaccination?
options: To induce immunological memory without causing severe disease
To treat active infections using high-dose chemical antibiotics
To boost the innate immune system's physical barriers permanently
To replace all natural immune functions with artificial ones
questions.explanation: Vaccines safely expose the immune system to antigens, priming memory B and T cells for rapid, strong response upon future exposure to the actual pathogen.

questions.question: What is in a typical vaccine?
options: Weakened, killed, or parts of pathogens (antigens)
Live, fully virulent pathogens capable of infection
Antibodies harvested from previously infected individuals
General immune system stimulants containing no antigens
questions.explanation: Vaccines contain antigenic material that triggers an immune response but doesn't cause disease: live-attenuated, inactivated, subunit, or mRNA/DNA vaccines.

questions.question: What is herd immunity?
options: When enough people are immune to protect those who aren't
When domestic animals transmit passive immunity to humans
When immunity spreads between people through physical contact
When only the genetically strongest individuals develop immunity
questions.explanation: High vaccination rates reduce pathogen circulation, protecting unvaccinated individuals (newborns, immunocompromised) by breaking transmission chains.

questions.question: What are memory cells in the context of vaccination?
options: Long-lived B and T cells that 'remember' vaccine antigens
Specialized brain cells that store vaccine-related information
Cells that immediately attack any pathogen through phagocytosis
Cells that produce antibodies only during the initial injection
questions.explanation: Vaccination stimulates production of memory lymphocytes that persist for years/decades, ready to mount rapid secondary response if the real pathogen appears.

questions.question: What is the difference between active and passive immunity?
options: Active: body produces its own antibodies; Passive: receives antibodies from another source
Active: provides immediate protection; Passive: provides delayed protection
Active: provides temporary defense; Passive: provides permanent defense
There is no functional difference between these two immune processes
questions.explanation: Vaccination induces active immunity (body makes its own memory cells). Passive immunity involves receiving antibodies (maternal, therapeutic) for temporary protection.

questions.question: Why might booster shots be necessary?
options: To enhance or renew immunological memory over time
Because the first vaccine dose never actually functions
To treat active infections that occur after the first dose
To replace the innate immune system's primary barriers
questions.explanation: Memory may wane; boosters re-expose immune system to antigens, strengthening memory cell populations and antibody levels for longer protection.

questions.question: What is an mRNA vaccine (like some COVID-19 vaccines)?
options: Contains mRNA instructions for cells to make viral protein antigens
Contains a live virus that actively produces mRNA in the blood
Contains pre-made antibodies targeted against viral mRNA
Contains viral DNA fragments instead of RNA genetic material
questions.explanation: mRNA vaccines deliver genetic instructions for making a harmless viral protein; our cells produce the protein, triggering immune response without using actual virus.

questions.question: What was Edward Jenner's contribution to vaccination?
options: Used cowpox to create the first effective smallpox vaccine
Discovered the first antibiotics for bacterial infections
Invented the first microscope to visualize tiny pathogens
Developed the first effective vaccine for the polio virus
questions.explanation: Jenner observed milkmaids exposed to cowpox didn't get smallpox; he inoculated a boy with cowpox material, providing cross-protection against smallpox (1796).

questions.question: Why is it generally impossible to get the disease from most vaccines?
options: They contain killed, weakened, or only parts of pathogens
Vaccines contain high doses of antibiotics that kill pathogens
The body destroys the vaccine pathogen within seconds of entry
All vaccines are made using completely different organisms
questions.explanation: Modern vaccines are designed to be non-pathogenic while still antigenic - they trigger immune response without causing illness.

questions.question: What role do adjuvants play in vaccines?
options: Enhance the immune response to the specific vaccine antigens
Kill any live pathogens accidentally present in the vaccine
Provide necessary nutritional support to active immune cells
Improve the taste and shelf-stability of oral vaccine doses
questions.explanation: Adjuvants are additives that stimulate stronger/longer immune responses, allowing smaller antigen doses and fewer boosters.
